questions.text: The arrangement of the functional columns of cranial nerve nuclei from ventral to dorsal aspect in the brainstem is as follows:

choices.text: Visceral Efferent > Somatic Efferent >  Visceral Afferent  > Somatic Afferent
Somatic Efferent > Visceral Efferent > Visceral Afferent > Somatic Afferent
Somatic Afferent > Visceral Afferent > Visceral Efferent >  Somatic Efferent
Visceral Efferent > Visceral Afferent > Somatic Afferent > Somatic Efferent

questions.solution:
The pattern of the arrangement of cranial nerve nuclei from the ventral to dorsal aspect is:

Somatic Efferent > Visceral Efferent > Visceral Afferent > Somatic Afferent

The basal and alar cranial nerve nuclei of the brainstem are organized into 7 columns. The sequence of the columns from ventral to dorsal is shown in the image below - 3 motor columns in the ventral basal plate (green) and 4 sensory columns in the dorsal alar plate (blue). The visceral nuclei are closer to the sulcus limitans than the somatic nuclei.

questions.text: A newborn boy had no passage of meconium for two days after birth. Examination revealed anal agenesis with perineal fistula. Which of the following is the most likely​ cause?

choices.text: Failure of perforation of anal membrane
Incomplete separation of cloaca by urorectal septum
Failure of recanalization of the colon

questions.solution:
Incomplete separation of cloaca by the urorectal septum causes anal agenesis.

When the urorectal septum is formed, the cloacal membrane gets divided into urogenital membrane anteriorly and anal membrane posteriorly. The ectoderm in the region of the future anal opening is called proctodeum. The proctodeum invaginates and creates the anal pit. The anal membrane now separates the hindgut from the anal pit. 

Formation of the anal canal takes place as follows:

  • The upper part of the anal canal is formed by the endodermal hindgut and the lower part by the ectodermal anal pit.
  • The anal membrane in between breaks around the 9th week and the anal canal becomes continuous. 
  • The junction between the endodermal and the ectodermal region of the anal canal is marked by the pectinate line.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about meninges is false?

choices.text: Endosteal layer of the dura mater is the periosteum of skull bones
Meningeal layer divides the cranial cavity into freely communicating spaces
Dural venous sinuses are present between the endosteal and the meningeal layer
Both endosteal and meningeal layer contain fibroblasts and osteoblasts

questions.solution:
Both the endosteal and meningeal layers contain fibroblasts, but only the endosteal layer contains osteoblasts.

The dura mater is made of the following 2 layers:

Endosteal layer Meningeal layer
Periosteum of the skull bones Dura mater proper
Contains fibroblasts and osteoblasts Contains only fibroblasts (no osteoblasts)
Not continuous with the spinal dura mater Continuous with the spinal dura mater
  It forms 4 septa that divide the cranial cavity into spaces restricting the displacement of the brain

The dural venous sinuses are present between the meningeal and the endosteal layer of the dura mater.

The four septa that divide the cranial cavity into freely communicating spaces are: 

  • Falx cerebri
  • Tentorium cerebelli
  • Falx cerebelli
  • Diaphragma sellae

questions.text: MRI of the coronal section of the brain is given to you. Which of the following nuclei of the marked structure does not project to neocortex?
questions.solution:
The marked structure is the thalamus. The reticular nucleus of the thalamus does not project to the neocortex. Its output is mainly to the other thalamic nuclei.

All other thalamic nuclei send output to the neocortex.

questions.text: A major part of the post-renal segment of the inferior vena cava develops from which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
The post-renal segment of the inferior vena cava (IVC) mainly develops from the right supracardinal vein.

In embryonic life, the supracardinal veins get a large amount of venous drainage from the growing body wall. The right supracardinal vein persists and forms the greater part of the postrenal segment of the inferior vena cava. 

The inferior vena cava is a composite vessel that develops from the remodeling of successive venous complexes. The veins contributing to the formation of IVC from upwards to below are as follows:

  1. Cardiac termination of the right vitelline vein, also known as the right hepatocardiac channel
  2. Anastomosis between right vitelline and right subcardinal veins (Hepatic segment of IVC)
  3. Right subcardinal vein (Subcardinal or Pre-renal segment of IVC)
  4. Anastomosis between right supracardinal and right subcardinal veins (Renal segment of IVC)
  5. Part of the right supracardinal vein (Supracardinal or Post-renal segment of IVC)
  6. Anastomosis between right supracardinal and right postcardinal veins
  7. Part of the right posterior cardinal vein
  8. Common iliac veins

questions.text: A patient with past history of parotidectomy now presents with sweating and flushing of skin over the cheek during mastication. Which of the following nerves is involved in this case?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario is suggestive of Frey's syndrome which involves the auriculotemporal nerve, marked as 2. 

Other structures marked are: 

1 - Maxillary nerve 

3 - Posterior auricular nerve 

4 - Inferior alveolar nerve

The auriculotemporal nerve is identified by its two roots which encircle the middle meningeal artery. It is a branch from the posterior division of the mandibular nerve. It gives cutaneous innervation to the tragus and the adjoining part of the auricle and carries postganglionic secretomotor fibers to the parotid gland. 

Frey's syndrome is caused due to aberrant regeneration of the postganglionic parasympathetic nerve fibers of the auriculotemporal nerve. The nerve fibres regenerate into the nearby sweat glands. It can occur following parotid surgery, or any trauma where there is an injury to the parotid capsule. This results in sweating, warmth, and redness of the face during the salivary stimulation by the smell or taste of food. Hence, Frey's syndrome is also known as gustatory sweating or auriculotemporal syndrome.

questions.text: The sensory fibers from the taste buds in the hard and soft palate travel along the ____.
questions.solution:
The sensory fibers from the taste buds in the hard and soft palate travel along the trigeminal nerve.

The taste sensation from taste buds in the oral surface of the soft palate is carried by the lesser palatine nerve.

The taste fibers initially travel in the greater petrosal nerve (a branch of the facial nerve) and pass through the pterygopalatine ganglion without synapsing.

questions.text: The labyrinthine artery most commonly arises from which of the following arteries?
questions.solution:
The labyrinthine artery is most commonly a branch of the anterior inferior cerebellar artery (AICA). It can also be a direct branch of the basilar artery at times.

The basilar artery is formed by the union of two vertebral arteries. At the upper border of the pons, it divides into two posterior cerebral arteries.

questions.text: A 23-year-old patient was referred for evaluation of a progressive left-hand weakness and pain involving his right medial elbow, forearm, wrist and thumb. Suspecting pure neuritic leprosy, a nerve biopsy was taken and the image of the histological section is given below. What is the stain used in this section?
questions.solution:
The stain used in this section is osmium tetroxide. 

Osmium tetroxide is reduced to a black substance by unsaturated fatty acids present in the myelin sheath of the nerve fibers and hence, appears black on the section.

The pure neuritic form is a variant of leprosy characterized by the isolated involvement of peripheral nerve trunks with the absence of skin lesions. Nerve biopsy is the gold standard method for the diagnosis of pure neuritic leprosy.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man was undergoing aortic bypass surgery. During the procedure, the surgeon accidentally injured an artery arising from the aorta. This artery provides major blood supply to the spinal cord on the left side at the lower thoracic level. Which region is likely to be affected?

choices.text: Upper two thirds of the spinal cord
Lower two thirds of the spinal cord
Upper one third of the spinal cord
Lower one third of the spinal cord

questions.solution:
The artery of Adamkiewicz supplies the lower two-thirds of the spinal cord. It is unilateral and in majority of the people, enters the spinal cord from the left side. 

The anterior spinal artery (ASA) is augmented by numerous radicular arteries. The most prominent of these is the artery of Adamkiewicz. It originates from the aorta in the lower thoracic or upper lumbar vertebral levels and has the following course:

Aorta - posterior intercostal artery - radicular artery - artery of Adamkiewicz - anastomosis with the anterior spinal artery(ASA).

Clinical significance:

It is a major source of blood supply for the lower 2/3rd of the cord. Damage to this artery can lead to paraplegia. Ischemia of the anterior segment is associated with the aortic bypass procedure.

questions.text: The septum pellucidum extends between:
questions.solution:
Septum pellucidum extends between the corpus callosum and the fornix. 

The septum pellucidum is a membrane separating the anterior horns of the left and right lateral ventricles of the brain. It extends from the corpus callosum to the fornix.

It develops from the lamina terminalis. The part of the lamina terminalis that stretches between corpus callosum and fornix persists as septum pellucidum.

The image given below shows the septum pellucidum.

questions.text: A patient presents with pain in one of her fingers. Kanavel's sign is positive. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Kanavel's sign is suggestive of tenosynovitis.

Clinically, it can distinguish infectious tenosynovitis from superficial or localized abcess.

Kanavel's sign has the following effects - 

  1. Tenderness over affected tendon
  2. Fusiform swelling over affected tendon
  3. The affected finger is in slight flexion
  4. Pain on passive extension of the affected finger

questions.text: Which of the following statements about brachial plexus is false?

choices.text: Nerve to subclavius arises from superior trunk
Arterial supply to brachial plexus is from branches of common carotid arteries
Radial nerve is the largest branch of the entire brachial plexus
C4 contributes to brachial plexus occasionally

questions.solution:
Arterial supply to brachial plexus is from branches of subclavian and vertebral arteries, and not from carotid arteries. 

The upper/superior trunk of the brachial plexus gives two branches:

  • Suprascapular nerve (C5, C6)
  • Nerve to the subclavius (C5, C6)

Radial nerve (C5, C6, C7, C8, T1) is the largest branch of the brachial plexus. It originates as the terminal branch of the posterior cord of the plexus.

Brachial plexus variations can be 2 types:

  • C4 pre-fixed brachial plexus 
  • T2 post-fixed brachial plexus

Related Pearl: Brachial Plexus

  • Covered by prevertebral fascia extension called "axillary sheath"

  • Middle trunk: C7.

  • Posterior cord: Formed by all 3 posterior divisions 
  • Medial cord: Formed by anterior division of the lower trunk.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a content of the superficial perineal pouch?
questions.solution:
Bulbourethral glands are not a content of the superficial perineal pouch. They are located in the deep perineal pouch. 

The superficial perineal pouch is a potential space between the perineal membrane above and the membranous layer of perineal fascia (Colle's fascia) below.

Males Common to both Females
Root of the penis Urethra Body of the clitoris

Muscles:

  • Corpora spongiosa

  • Ischiocavernosus

  • Posterior scrotum
  • Bulb of penis

Perineal nerve branches:

  • Labia

  • Posterior scrotal artery
  • Branches of the penile artery

questions.text: The given image shows the posterior thoracic wall. Which of the following statements is false about the structure marked A within the intercostal space?

choices.text: It is located below the intercostal artery
Derivatives from T4 and T5 are typical in type
They lie between external intercostal and internal intercostal muscle
Derivatives from T7 to T11 supply the abdominal wall

questions.solution:
The structure marked A is the intercostal nerve. It doesn't lie between external and internal intercostal muscles, but lies between the internal and innermost intercostal muscles. 

Intercostal nerves are derived from the ventral rami of the thoracic vertebrae - T1 to T11. They lie between the internal intercostal and innermost intercostal muscles.

Typical intercostal nerves are those that only supply only the thoracic wall, e.g, 3rd to 6th intercostal nerves. All the other intercostal nerves supply other regions as follows:

  • Upper two intercostal nerves - supply upper limb
    • 1st intercostal nerve - does not have the lateral and anterior cutaneous branches.
    • 2nd intercostal nerve - gives off the intercostobrachial nerve
  • 7th to 11th intercostal nerves - supply abdominal wall, hence they are called thoracoabdominal nerves. 

In each intercostal space, the arrangement of the structures superior to inferior is vein, artery, nerve (VAN). In the 1st intercostal space, the neurovascular bundle lies superiorly, and the arrangement from medial to lateral is the Sympathetic trunk, intercostal Vein, superior intercostal Artery, intercostal Nerve. (SVAN).

questions.text: Which part of the epididymis contains sperms with low amplitude and high-frequency tail movements?
questions.solution:
The tail of the epididymis (marked as C) contains sperms with low amplitude and high-frequency tail movements.

The motility of sperm plays an important role in the process of fertilization. Sperms acquire their motility and maturation in the epididymis.

Head of the epididymis Tail of the epididymis

High amplitude and low-frequency tail movements

Low amplitude and high-frequency tail movements
Responsible for the subtle motion of the sperms

Responsible for the rapid forward progression and aids in fertilization

The epididymis has the following three parts:

Parts of the epididymis Features
Head Receives the immature spermatozoa from the superior pole of the testis through the efferent ducts
Body

Efferent ducts from the head open into the tubules of the epididymis

These tubules coalesce forming a single, highly coiled tubule

The wall of the body contains smooth muscles which propel the sperms towards the tail during ejaculation
Tail The coiled tubule passes through the tail and continues as the vas deferens

Clinical note: Cystic degeneration of epididymis can result in epididymal cysts.

questions.text: A golfer hurt himself after he accidentally hit the ground while taking a shot. He has tenderness in the area shown in the image below. On examination, he has pain radiating to his ring and little finger. Which of the following bones is most likely to be fractured?
questions.solution:
In the above scenario, the area of tenderness and the pain in the ring and little finger are suggestive of the hook of hamate fracture. The pain in the ring and little finger is related to the close proximity of the ulnar nerve which could get affected due to a fracture of hook of hamate.

The hamate is cuneiform and bears an unciform hamulus (hook) that projects from the distal part of its rough palmar surface.

Mnemonic for Carpal Bones -

She(S) - Scaphoid

Looks(L) - Lunate

Too(T) - Triquetral

Pretty(P) - Pisiform

Try (T) - Trapezium 

To(T) - Trapezoid

Catch(C) - Capitate

Her(H) - Hamate

questions.text: Broca’s area is situated in the __________.
questions.solution:
Broca’s area is situated in the inferior frontal gyrus.

Broca’s motor speech area (44,45) is located in the inferior frontal gyrus.

Wernicke’s area (22) is located in the superior temporal gyrus.

questions.text: A 2-month-old baby was brought to the clinic with an anomaly as shown in the image. This occurs due to the failure of fusion between which structures?

choices.text: Lateral nasal prominence and mandibular prominence
Lateral nasal prominence and maxillary prominence
Medial nasal prominence and mandibular prominence
Medial nasal prominence and maxillary prominence

questions.solution:
The image shows cleft lip which occurs when the maxillary prominences fail to fuse with the medial nasal prominences.

Various defects of fusion of prominences in the face region are as follows: 

A cleft lip is due to the failure of the fusion of maxillary prominence with medial nasal prominence. It can be unilateral or bilateral. It can vary in severity from a small notch in the upper lip to a double cleft extending into both the nostrils. There is also associated underdevelopment of the part of the maxilla that bears the incisors. 

Median (midline) cleft lip is a rare defect occurring due to failure of the two medial nasal prominences to fuse in the midline. 

The oblique facial cleft is caused by the failure of the maxillary prominence to fuse with the lateral nasal prominence along the line of the nasolacrimal groove. The nasolacrimal duct is exposed to the surface in these cases.

questions.text: All of the following structures are lined by transitional epithelium except_______
questions.solution:
Pseudostratified columnar epithelium lines the membranous urethra.

The transitional epithelium is identified by the variations in the cell layers: the deepest cell layer is columnar or cuboidal, the middle is made of polyhedral cells, and, lastly, the surface cells are large and umbrella-shaped.

Transitional epithelium lines the renal pelvis and calyces, the ureter, the urinary bladder, and the pre-prostatic and prostatic parts of the urethra. Because of this distribution, it is also called the urothelium. In the urinary bladder, it is usually observed that transitional epithelium can be stretched considerably without being damaged. When stretched, it appears to be thinner and the cells become flattened or rounded.  

The following are various parts of the urethra in males and their lining epithelium:
  • Pre-prostatic & Prostatic urethra - Transitional epithelium
  • Membranous urethra - Pseudostratified columnar epithelium
  • Penile/ Spongy urethra - proximally, Pseudostratified columnar; distally, stratified squamous.

In both males and females, the greater part of the urethra is lined by pseudostratified columnar epithelium. A short part adjoining the urinary bladder is lined by transitional epithelium, while the part near the external orifice is lined by stratified squamous epithelium.

The image given below shows transitional epithelium.

Related Pearl: Various Types of Epithelium, Their Location and Functions

questions.text: A 24-year-old man presents to the ER after receiving a punch to the right side of his face. His X-ray is shown below. Which of the following bones maximally contributes to the region fractured?
questions.solution:
The X-ray shows a fracture of the floor of the orbit. The maximum contribution to the floor of the orbit is by the maxilla.

Boundaries of the bony orbit:

  • Roof: 
    • Orbital plate of frontal bone 
    • Sphenoid bone (small part)
  • Floor: Thin plate of bone that also forms the roof of the maxillary sinus
    • Orbital plate of maxilla
    • Zygomatic bone (anterolateral)
    • Orbital process of palatine bone (posteromedial)
  • Medial wall:
    • Maxilla
    • Lacrimal bone
    • Ethmoid bone
    • Sphenoid bone
  • Lateral wall: 
    • Zygomatic bone (anterior)
    • Greater wing of sphenoid (posterior)
    • Sphenozygomatic suture.

The orbital floor can be fractured by trauma to the orbit as seen in falls, motor vehicle accidents, and assaults. The image given shows X-ray Water's view with a 'teardrop' sign. The orbital contents leak out of the fractured orbital floor, giving it a teardrop-like appearance.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man had an RTA resulting in the following gait abnormality. What is the largest part of the affected structure?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of post-traumatic cerebellar ataxia presenting with impaired balance. The largest part of the affected structure i.e. the cerebellum is the middle lobe, also known as the posterior lobe. The gait shown in the above video is a cerebellar ataxic gait. Here, the patient is seen attempting tandem walking and displaying improper heel-toe coordination, erratic foot placement, and truncal swaying.

The cerebellum consists of two hemispheres (right and left) joined by a median vermis. It is divided into three lobes:

  • Anterior lobe - lies superiorly above the primary fissure
  • Middle lobe - lies inferiorly below the primary fissure
  • Flocculonodular lobe - lies posterior to the uvulonodular fissure

It has two surfaces, superior and inferior, separated by a horizontal fissure. It is connected to the other parts of the central nervous system via three peduncles.

questions.text: The midgut loop normally herniates through the primitive umbilical ring into the extra-embryonic celom during the 6th-week of development. Failure of the intestinal loops to return to the abdominal cavity by 11th-week results in the formation of which of the following conditions in a baby?
questions.solution:
Failure of the intestinal loops to return to the abdominal cavity during the 6th to 10th weeks results in omphalocele or exomphalos.

Omphalocele is a congenital malformation in which the abdominal viscera protrudes through a wide umbilical defect. The bowel loops are covered by amnion. 

A small omphalocele contains only the intestines. A large omphalocele may contain other viscera such as the stomach, liver, spleen, and large intestine, along with the small intestine. Omphalocele is commonly associated with other congenital anomalies (e.g., trisomy 13, trisomy 18, or Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome) and causes increased levels of α-fetoprotein. 

The images given below shows the omphalocele.

Note: Gastroschisis is the major disorder to consider in the differential diagnosis of an omphalocele. It can be differentiated from omphalocele by its absence of a membranous sac and paraumbilical location (commonly to the right of the umbilicus).

Related Pearl: Difference between gastroschisis and omphalocele

Characteristic Gastroschisis Omphalocele
Defect size (diameter) 2-3 cm 2-15 cm

questions.text: All of the following muscles are paralysed in case of lesion of lower part of posterior interosseous nerve except?
questions.solution:
Extensor Carpi Radialis Brevis (ECRB) is supplied by deep branch, of radial nerve before the nerve enters the arcade of Frohse, hence not paralysed by lesion of the lower part of Posterior Interosseous Nerve (PIN).

Radial nerve branches in cubital fossa

  • Deep Br
  • Superficial Br

Deep branch continues as Posterior interosseous nerve (PIN) (Some authours call both deep branch and PIN together as PIN, creating confusion) 

  • Deep branch - Supplies supinator and ECRB 
  • Name change - After piercing supinator muscle and exiting posteriorly, it changes its name from deep branch to PIN
  • PIN - supplies extensors: APL, EPB, EI, ED, EDM, ECU

Superficial branch - Becomes cutaneous at dorsum of hand and innervates the lateral aspect of dorsum of hand.

 

Extensor carpi radialis brevis is supplied by two branches - one from the trunk of radial nerve and second branch from posterior interosseous nerve. There is variation in the level at which branches to extensor carpi radialis brevis arise. It may arise from the main trunk of the radial nerve or from the proximal part of posterior interosseous nerve.

questions.text: In the post-ductal coarctation of aorta, which of the following distal anastomotic artery is not involved?
questions.solution:
This is a controversial question as all of the given arteries participate in the given anastomosis.

  • In Grays anatomy, there is no mention of the vertebral artery in the topic, and hence, it is taken as the answer of choice.
  • The aortic lumen is occasionally partly or completely obliterated at a level above (preductal or infantile type), opposite, or just beyond (postductal or adult type) the entry of the ductus arteriosus.
  • The postductal type of coarctation may permit years of normal life, allowing the development of an extensive collateral circulation to the aorta distal to the stenosis.
  • Arteries arising indirectly from the aorta proximal to the coarctation segment anastomose with vessels connected with it distal to the block, and all of these vessels become greatly enlarged.

questions.text: Which of the following is the action of the muscle inserted to the area marked below?
questions.solution:
The marked area on the mandible is the pterygoid fovea where the lateral pterygoid muscle is inserted. The action of this muscle is depression, protrusion, and side to side movement of the jaw.

Lateral pterygoid muscle:

  • Origin - Upper head arises from the infratemporal surface and infratemporal crest of the greater wing of the sphenoid bone. The lower head arises from the lateral surface of the lateral pterygoid plate. 
  • Insertion - It is inserted into the pterygoid fovea, the capsule of the temporomandibular joint, and the articular disc.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the bronchopulmonary segment?

choices.text: It is named according to the segmental bronchus supplying it
It is drained by independent intrasegmental branch of pulmonary vein
It is the largest subdivision of a lobe

questions.solution:
The bronchopulmonary segments are not drained by an independent branch of the pulmonary vein.

The tributaries of the pulmonary vein tend to pass intersegmentally between and around the margins of segments.

A bronchopulmonary segment is the area of lung supplied by a segmental bronchus and its accompanying pulmonary artery branch and can be resected surgically. It is the largest division of a lobe.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the ascending spinal tracts is incorrect?

choices.text: II order neurons of dorsal column form the medial lemniscus
Axons from nucleus gracilis and nucleus cuneatus form internal arcuate fibres
III order neurons of spinothalamic tract terminate  in ventral posterolateral nucleus of thalamus
II order neurons of spinothalamic tract form the spinal lemniscus

questions.solution:
III order neurons of the spinothalamic tract do not terminate in ventral posterolateral nucleus of thalamus. They arise from this thalamic nuclei. 

In the dorsal column, the II order neurons are axons from nucleus gracilis and nucleus cuneatus which form internal arcuate fibers. These crossover to the contralateral side to form medial lemniscus which terminates by synapsing in the ventral posterolateral nucleus of the thalamus. (Option A and B)

In the spinothalamic tract, the II order neurons ascend to the lower brainstem where the axons in the lateral tract form the spinal meniscus.(Option D) This continues to ascend and terminates by synapsing in the ventral posterolateral nucleus of the thalamus. The III order neurons arise from this nucleus which projects to the somatosensory cortex. 

This MCQ has been revised for factual accuracy.

questions.text: Identify the structure labelled in the diagram below.
questions.solution:
Structure labelled in the picture is artery piercing the clavipectoral fascia called thoracoacromial artery.

Clavipectoral fascia envelops the subclavius and pectoralis minor. Medially it forms the costocoracoid ligament. Laterally it is connected to the axillary fascia by suspensory ligament of axilla (Gerdy's ligament). The structures piercing clavipectoral fascia are:

  • 1 vein: Cephalic vein
  • 1 artery: Thoraco­acromial artery (associated veins and lymphatics)
  • 1 nerve: Lateral pectoral nerve.

questions.text: A 72-year-old patient who suffered a stroke is unable to swallow food.  On examination, the gag reflex is absent. The motor nucleus of the vagus nerve involved here emerges from _______ of the brainstem.
questions.solution:
The fibers from the nucleus ambiguus emerge through the postero-lateral sulcus of the brainstem.  

Nucleus ambiguus is made of cranial nerves IX, X, and XI. 

The following table describes the components of the vagal nerve and the associated nuclei.

questions.text: All the following statements regarding suboccipital triangle are true except:

choices.text: Posterior atlanto occipital membrane forms the floor of this triangle
3rd part of Vertebral artery is seen in the triangle
Lesser occipital nerve and sub occipital venous plexus are other contents

questions.solution:
Lesser occipital nerve and suboccipital venous plexus are not the contents of the suboccipital triangle.

Suboccipital triangle: 

  • It is bounded by rectus capitis posterior major superomedially, obliquus capitis superior superolaterally, and obliquus capitis inferolaterally.
  • The roof is formed by dense adipose tissue deep to semispinalis capitis, longissimus capitis muscle and sometimes splenius capitis.
  • The floor is formed  by posterior atlanto-occipital membrane and the posterior arch of the atlas.
  • Contents of suboccipital triangle are 3rd part of vertebral artery, sub occipital nerve (dorsal ramus of c1) and suboccipital venous plexus.

questions.text: Which of the following will you test in patients with median nerve injury at the wrist?

choices.text: Loss of sensation of the palm
Loss of sensation on the ring finger

questions.solution:
Injury to the median nerve at the wrist is tested by contraction of the abductor pollicis brevis. Loss of thumb mobility and opposition (abductor pollicis brevis) is tested by pen test. 

Option A: Paralysis of flexor pollicis brevis can occur in median nerve injury at the arm and elbow. Benediction hand sign (attempt to make a fist gives pointed index and middle finger) and Ochsner's clasping test (attempt to clasp both hands show pointing index finger) are used to test such injuries.

The images below show the Benediction hand sign and Ochsner's clasping test.

Option B: The lateral 1/2 of the palm is supplied by the palmar cutaneous branch of the median nerve. It is usually spared in median nerve injury to the wrist as it does not pass through the carpal tunnel. 

Option D: The loss of sensation over ring finger cannot be tested for median nerve injury as it supplies:

  • Lateral half of palmar aspect
  • Medial half of distal 1/3 of dorsal aspect

Note: Out of three muscles in the thenar eminence only abductor pollicis brevis and opponens pollicis can be tested for isolated action. Flexor pollicis brevis cannot be tested for isolated action.

questions.text: What is the final step of maturation of spermatozoon before fertilization known as?
questions.solution:
The final step of maturation of spermatozoon before fertilization is known as capacitation.

Capacitation involves a period of conditioning of the sperm in the female reproductive tract, predominantly in the uterine tube. It provides the sperms with the ability to penetrate the outer layer of the ovum. Chemical changes in the tail provide them with greater mobility. It lasts approximately 7 hours.

questions.text: A child is diagnosed to have an aneurysmal malformation of a vessel located in the marked structure. Identify the structure and the vessel present in it.
questions.solution:
The area marked "A" is the quadrigeminal cistern, and it contains the great cerebral vein of Galen.

Aneurysmal malformation of the great cerebral vein of Galen is a congenital anomaly occurring due to the persistence of the embryonic prosencephalic vein of Markowski.

questions.text: Which cranial nerve nucleus is not found on the floor of the fourth ventricle?
questions.solution:
The VII cranial nerve nucleus is not present on the floor of the fourth ventricle.

The floor of the fourth ventricle is diamond-shaped and lies on the dorsal surface of the pons and superior half of the medulla.

It is divided into two symmetrical halves by the longitudinal median sulcus. Each half is further divided by sulcus limitans into a medial region, medial eminence, and a lateral region, vestibular area. The vestibular nuclei lie beneath the vestibular area.

At the superior end of the sulcus limitans, a bluish-gray area is produced by a cluster of nerve cells containing melanin pigment called substantia ferruginea.

At the inferior end of the medial eminence, the fibers from the motor nucleus of the facial nerve looping over the abducens nucleus are represented by the facial colliculus.

Inferiorly, the medial eminence is represented by the hypoglossal triangle overlying the hypoglossal nucleus and the vagal triangle overlying the dorsal nucleus of the vagus.

questions.text: The most important anatomical structure that supports bulk of the liver in its position in right upper abdomen is ______

choices.text: Tone in the anterolateral abdominal muscles
Ligamentous attachments of liver capsule to the diaphragm and anterior abdominal wall
Hepatic veins attaching Liver to the relatively fixed retroperitoneal inferior vena cava
Support offered by right kidney and right colic flexure

questions.solution:
Inferior vena cava and the hepatic veins, especially right hepatic vein are the most important anatomical structures that support bulk of the Liver. The hepatic veins do not have an extra hepatic course, so the IVC is flush against the bulk of the liver.

Clinical Note:  After orthotropic liver transplantation, despite the absence of ligamentous structures, the liver remains within the right upper quadrant although it is more prone to torsion and rotation.

Factors that support liver in its position in the right upper quadrant of abdomen are as follows:

Primary factors:

  • Suspensory attachments at posterior abdominal wall to IVC
  • Hepatic veins
  • Coronary and triangular ligaments

Secondary factors:

  • Support provided by right kidney, right colic flexure and duodenopancreatic complex.

Tertiary factors:

  • Attachment to anterior abdominal wall and diaphragm by falciform ligament

questions.text: Identify the area marked 'a' in the figure below.
questions.solution:
The image is of the floor of the 4th ventricle, and the area marked 'a' is the hypoglossal triangle.

The floor of the 4th ventricle is diamond-shaped and lies on the dorsal surface of the pons and superior half of the medulla. It is divided into two symmetrical halves by the longitudinal median sulcus. Each half is further divided by sulcus limitans into a medial region, medial eminence, and a lateral region, vestibular area.

The vestibular nuclei lie beneath the vestibular area.

At the superior end of the sulcus limitans, a bluish-gray area is produced by a cluster of nerve cells containing melanin pigment called substantia ferruginea/locus coeruleus.

At the inferior end of the medial eminence, the fibers from the motor nucleus of the facial nerve looping over the abducens nucleus are represented by the facial colliculus.

Inferiorly, the medial eminence is represented by the hypoglossal triangle overlying the hypoglossal nucleus and the vagal triangle overlying the dorsal nucleus of the vagus.

questions.text: While examining the hypoglossal nerve in a stroke patient, you observe the following finding. Which of the following muscles is likely to be paralyzed?
questions.solution:
The given image shows tongue deviation to the left, and the left genioglossus muscle is paralyzed in the above given clinical scenario.

Actions of genioglossus muscle:

  • When both the right and left genioglossi contract, they protrude the anterior part of the tongue out of the mouth in the midline. When only one muscle contracts, it protrudes and pushes the tongue to the opposite side.
  • It depresses the central part of the tongue.
  • It is supplied by the hypoglossal nerve. 

In conditions affecting the hypoglossal nerve, the genioglossus muscle on that side is paralyzed. In such cases, when the patient protrudes the tongue, it deviates towards the affected side due to the muscle contraction on the normal side.

The genioglossi are attached to the genial tubercle present on the mandible. This prevents the tongue from falling backwards and obstructing respiration. Hence this muscle is known as the safety muscle of the tongue.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the nerve involved in the palsy shown below is false?

choices.text: It divides into upper and lower divisions in the anterior part of the cavernous sinus.
Its divisions enter the orbit through the middle part of the superior orbital fissure.
It lies between the posterior cerebral and superior cerebellar arteries in the interpeduncular fossa.
The nerve to inferior rectus carries parasympathetic fibers to the ciliary ganglion.

questions.solution:
The image shows oculomotor nerve palsy. The nerve to inferior oblique carries parasympathetic fibers to the ciliary ganglion, not the nerve to inferior rectus.

Course of the oculomotor nerve:

  • The nerve lies on the anterior surface of the midbrain in between the posterior cerebral artery and the superior cerebellar artery in the interpeduncular fossa.
  • It then passes to the middle cranial fossa along the lateral dural wall of the cavernous sinus and divides into superior and inferior in its anterior part.
  • It enters the superior orbital fissure through the common tendinous ring.

questions.text: Following radical mastectomy, the patient is unable to extend, adduct, and internally rotate the arm. Innervation to which of the following muscles is likely to be damaged?
questions.solution:
In the above scenario, innervation to latissimus dorsi is most likely to be damaged.

Latissimus dorsi is innervated by the thoracodorsal nerve, which could be injured during radical mastectomy. It has the following actions on the arm:

  • Adduction
  • Medial rotation

questions.text: A 21-year-old student presents with a single episode of loss of consciousness. He was about to give a speech at his graduation ceremony when he suddenly turned pale and collapsed to the ground. Which of the following areas contain the nerve responsible for it?

questions.text: The nerve of the second branchial arch is:
questions.solution:
The facial nerve is the nerve of the 2nd pharyngeal arch. 

Each pharyngeal arch is characterized by its own muscular components. The muscular components of each arch have their own cranial nerve. Wherever the muscle cells migrate, they carry their nerve component with them.

The neurons of the 5th, 7th, 9th, and 10th cranial sensory ganglia that supply the pharyngeal arch structures are derived from ectodermal placodes (epipharyngeal placodes) and from the neural crest cells.

questions.text: What is the adult representation of the location of anterior neuropore?
questions.solution:
The location of the anterior neuropore is represented in adults as lamina terminalis. 

The anterior neuropore closes around the 25th day of intrauterine life. Its location in adults is represented by the lamina terminalis. The lamina terminalis forms the anterior boundary of the third ventricle.

The posterior neuropore closes around the 28th day of intrauterine life. Its location in adults is represented by the terminal ventricle. The terminal ventricle is present in the proximal 5 to 6 mm of filum terminale.

questions.text:
Arrange the following stages of nephron development in order from the earlier stage to the later stage.

1. Blastema stage
2. Comma 'C' stage
3. S-shaped stage
4. Vesicle stage
questions.solution:
The correct order of the stages of development of the nephron from earlier to later is blastema stage --> vesicle stage --> comma 'C' stage --> S-shaped stage.

The tip of the ureteric bud, which is growing towards the metanephric blastema, becomes dilated to form an ampulla. The ampulla induces the cells of the metanephric blastema to develop into a nephron.

The cells of the metanephric blastema pass through the following stages when developing into a nephron:

questions.text: The two elevations on the medial wall of the posterior horn of the lateral ventricle are due to _______.

choices.text: Tapetum of the corpus callosum and calcar avis

questions.solution:
The two elevations on the medial wall of the posterior horn of the lateral ventricle are due to the forceps major and calcar avis. 

The posterior horn extends from the splenium to the occipital pole. The relations are: 

  • Roof and lateral wall - Tapetum of corpus callosum
  • Medial wall - Forceps major and calcar avis (calcarine sulcus)

The forceps major is the fibers of the splenium of the corpus callosum.

The calcar avis is formed by the white matter of the calcarine sulcus.

Forceps minor is formed by the anterior part of the corpus callosum.

The collateral eminence is formed by the collateral sulcus and is related to the floor of the inferior horn of the lateral ventricle.

Related Pearl: Corpus Callosum

Parts of the corpus callosum:

  • Rostrum: connects frontal lobes (eg: orbitofrontal cortex)
  • Genu: connects frontal lobes. It is the anterior-most part.
  • Trunk or Body: connects temporal lobes.
  • Splenium: connects the two occipital lobes. It is the thickest part.

Note: Isthmus is a part which separates the body from splenium, some books mention it as a part.

  • The fibers of the genu curve forward into frontal lobes and form forceps minor.
  • The fibers of the trunk extend laterally as radiation of corpus callosum.
  • The fibers from the trunk and the splenium which form the lateral wall of the inferior horn of the lateral ventricle constitute the tapetum.
  • The fibers from the splenium arching backwards into the occipital lobe form forceps major.

questions.text: A man sustained a head injury 6 weeks back, following a road traffic accident. Now, he complains of increased frequency of urination and excessive thirst. An injury to which nucleus is likely to cause the given condition?
questions.solution:
Lesion of the supraoptic nucleus of the hypothalamus causes inhibition of the synthesis of vasopressin leading to diabetes insipidus.

The hypothalamus is a part of the diencephalon that lies below the thalamus. 

  • Anteriorly, the preoptic area is included in the hypothalamus.
  • Posteriorly, it merges with the tegmentum of the midbrain.
  • Laterally, it is bounded by the internal capsule.

Microscopically, the hypothalamus is divided into multiple nuclei.

Related Pearl: Functions of Main Hypothalamic Nuclei

 

Hypothalamic Nucleus Function
Supraoptic  Synthesizes vasopressin (ADH)
Paraventricular Synthesizes oxytocin
Preoptic & anterior Nuclei Control parasymphathetic system
Posterior & Lateral Control symphathetic system
Anterior Regulate temperature(response to heat)
Posterior Regulate temperature(response to cold)
Lateral

Initiate eating and increase food intake (Hunger center)
Increase water intake (Thirst center)
Medial

Inhibit eating and reduce food intake (satiety center)

Suprachiasmatic

 Controls circadian rhythm

questions.text: A patient with chronic otitis media and mastoiditis develops thrombosis of the sinus marked below. Which of the following sinuses does it drain from?
questions.solution:
The sinus marked in the image is the sigmoid sinus. It drains from the transverse sinus. 

It passes through an S-shaped groove in the mastoid process of the temporal bone, courses over the jugular process of the occipital bone, and emerges posterior to the jugular foramen. 

The sigmoid sinus receives tributaries: 

  • Mastoid emissary veins
  • Condylar emissary veins
  • Venous plexus of the hypoglossal canal
  • Inferior cerebellar veins 
  • Unnamed tributaries from the pons and medulla 

It joins the inferior petrosal sinus to form the internal jugular vein.

Sigmoid/lateral sinus thrombosis occurs as a complication of ear or mastoid infection. 

Related Pearl: Dural Venous Sinuses

Dural venous sinus Drains into
Unpaired sinuses
Superior sagittal sinus Confluence of sinuses or continues as right transverse sinus
Inferior sagittal sinus joins the great cerebral vein to form the straight sinus
 Straight sinus forms the left transverse sinus
Occipital sinus Confluence of sinuses
Paired sinuses
Superior petrosal sinus transverse sinus
Inferior petrosal sinus Internal jugular vein
Transverse sinus continue as sigmoid sinus
Sigmoid sinus continuous with the internal jugular vein
Cavernous sinus Superior and inferior petrosal sinuses

questions.text: The movements at the ____________ joint permit a person to look to the right and left.
questions.solution:
The movements at the atlanto-axial joint allow a person to look left and right.

The atlanto-axial joints include 3 synovial joints:

  • Median atlanto-axial joint- The central pivot joint between the dens of the axis and a ring formed by the anterior arch and transverse atlantal ligament 
  • Lateral atlanto-axial joints- Plain synovial joints between lateral masses of atlas and upper facets of the body of axis

Movements at the atlanto-axial joint almost exclusively is rotation around the axis, which help side-to-side rotation of the head. The normal range of atlanto-axial rotation is about 40°.

questions.text: The structure (Red Arrow) shown in the image develops from _______
questions.solution:
The arrow depicts the neurohypophysis which develops from the diencephalon.

The pituitary has two major parts, the neurohypophysis and adenohypophysis, which differ in their origin, structure and function.

The neurohypophysis is a diencephalic downgrowth connected with the hypothalamus.

The adenohypophysis is an ectodermal derivative of the stomatodeum.

questions.text:
Which of the following structures is not present in the plane marked as 1 in the image?
  1. Origin of the celiac trunk
  2. Origin of the portal vein
  3. Lower limit of the spinal cord in newborn
  4. Lower limit of the spinal cord in adults
  5. Cisterna chyli
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the image is the transpyloric plane which is present at L1 level. The origin of the celiac trunk (T12) and lower limit of the spinal cord of a newborn (L3) are not present at this level.

The transpyloric plane (Addison's plane) passes midway between the suprasternal notch of the manubrium and the upper border of the pubic symphysis. This approximately corresponds to midway between the xiphisternal joint and the umbilicus. Posteriorly, this plane passes through the lower half of the body of the first lumbar vertebra (lower border of L1). 

Structures present in the transpyloric plane:

Organs  Neurovascular structures 
Pylorus of stomach Origin of the superior mesenteric artery
D1 part of the duodenum Origin of the renal artery
Duodenojejunal flexure Origin of the portal vein (behind the neck of the pancreas)
Fundus of the gallbladder Lower limit of the spinal cord in adults
Hilum of the left kidney (right kidney is slightly lower)  Cisterna chyli

 

Related Pearl: Abdominal planes and their landmarks

Planes that divide the abdomen into 9 regions are:

  • Horizontal planes 
    • At the level of L3 - Subcostal plane (between 10th costal cartilages). It corresponds to the 3rd part of the duodenum
    • At the level of L5 - Transtubercular plane (between tubercles of iliac crests). It corresponds to the origin of inferior vena cava. 
  • Vertical planes (paramedian or lateral planes)
    • From mid-clavicular point to mid-inguinal point on both sides 

The nine regions of the abdomen include:

  • Right hypochondriac, epigastric, left hypochondriac
  • Right lumbar, umbilical (central), left lumbar
  • Right iliac, hypogastric (suprapubic), left iliac

Other planes and angles in the abdomen are:

  • Transpyloric (Addison's) plane - passes midway between the suprasternal notch and the upper border of the pubic symphysis.
  • Supracristal plane - passes through the highest point of the iliac crest on both sides. It corresponds to the level of the L4 body or L4/5 disc and its spinous process. It is an important landmark when performing a lumbar puncture or spinal injection. The bifurcation of the abdominal aorta lies approximately in this plane.
  • The plane of the pubic crest - passes through the upper border of the pubic symphysis. In supine, this plane intersects the tip of the coccyx and the femoral head.
  • Renal angle - between the 12th rib and the outer border of erector spinae muscle. The lower border of normal kidneys may occasionally be felt here. 
  • Lumbar triangle of Petit - formed below by the iliac crest, anteriorly by external oblique, and posteriorly by latissimus dorsi. Lumbar hernia can occur here.

questions.text: While testing the cranial nerves in a stroke patient, you ask her to try to whistle. Which of the following structures doesn't pierce the muscle responsible for this action?

choices.text: Buccal branch of the facial nerve
Buccal branch of the mandibular nerve

questions.solution:
The buccinator muscle is involved in flattening the cheeks against the gums and teeth. Hence, it is known as the whistling muscle. The buccal branch of the facial nerve innervates the buccinator muscle but does not pierce it.

The structures piercing the buccinator muscle are:

  1. Parotid duct
  2. Buccal branch of the mandibular nerve
  3. Molar mucous glands which lie on the buccopharyngeal fascia around the parotid duct

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the iliopubic tract?

choices.text: It is a thickening of the lumbar fascia
It lies anterior to the Poupart's ligament
It inserts into the pubic tubercle in front of the conjoint tendon
Its fibers fan out with fascia iliaca laterally

questions.solution:
The fibers of the iliopubic tract fan out with fascia iliaca laterally.

The iliopubic tract is a thickening of the transversalis fascia lying immediately posterior to the inguinal (Poupart's) ligament. It extends from the anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS) superolaterally and arches across the front of the femoral sheath.

Attachments:

  • Medially, its fibres insert by a broad attachment into the pubic tubercle and pectineal line, behind the conjoint tendon. 
  • Laterally, its fibres fan out within the fascia transversalis and fascia iliaca without bony attachment to the iliac spines. 

Clinical note: It is considered as an important landmark in laparoscopic hernia surgeries.

questions.text: A patient with a history of parotidectomy presented with sweating over the cheek during meal times. To confirm the diagnosis, the parotid region was painted with dry corn starch, and the patient was asked to chew on a piece of gum. You observe the area changing color as shown below. Which of the following nerves form an aberrant connection here?

choices.text: Auriculotemporal nerve and chorda tympani nerve
Chorda tympani nerve and lingual nerve
Chorda tympani nerve and great auricular nerve
Auriculotemporal nerve and great auricular nerve

questions.solution:
The given case scenario is of Frey's syndrome. The auriculotemporal nerve and great auricular nerve form aberrant connections. 

In starch-iodine test, dry corn starch is applied to the affected area. In presence of gustatory sweating, the affected area turns blue after being exposed to the iodine in sweat. 

Frey's syndrome is also known as gustatory sweating or auriculotemporal syndrome.

It commonly develops after parotid surgery or any trauma where there is an injury to the parotid capsule.

During the regrowth, an aberrant connection develops between the parasympathetic fibres supplying the parotid gland (auriculotemporal nerve) and the sweat glands(great auricular nerve).

This results in sweating, warmth, and redness of the face during the salivary stimulation by the smell or taste of food.  

Management:

  • Antiperspirants - aluminium chloride
  • Tympanic neurectomy
  • Botulinum toxin injection into the affected skin

Gustatory sweating is known as Frey’s syndrome or auriculotemporal syndrome. It commonly develops after parotid surgery or any trauma where there is an injury to the parotid capsule. During the regrowth, an aberrant connection develops between the parasympathetic fibres supplying the parotid gland (auriculotemporal nerve) and the sweat glands (great auricular nerve). This results in sweating, warmth and redness of the face during the salivary stimulation by the smell or taste of food.

questions.text: Which of the following Cranial Nerve supply muscles derived from a somite?
questions.solution:
CN12 supplies occipital (postotic) myotome, occipital myotome is part of occipital somite.

Other options - 

Option a: CN3 supplies preotic myotome, preotic myotome is not a part of any somite. 

Option b: CN7 supplies pharyngeal arch myotome, the pharyngial arch is not part of somite. 

Option c: CN6 supplies preotic myotome 

Somite definition:

Somites are bilaterally paired blocks of paraxial mesoderm that form along the head-to-tail axis of the developing embryo.

In total there are 4 occipital, 8 cervical, 12 thoracic, 5 lumbar, 5 sacral and 8–10 coccygeal pairs, some of these degenerate later. 

Head and neck mesoderm:

  • Preotic mesoderm (front of "otic" embryonic ear).
  • Postotic or occipital mesoderm (the only somite-derived mesoderm in head and neck).
  • Pharyryngeal arch mesoderm (bulges in embryonic pharyngeal(neck) area).

Head and neck mesoderm supply: 

  • Preotic - CN3, CN4 and CN6, which forms extrinsic muscles of eye. 
  • Postotic or occipital - supplied by CN12, which form tongue muscles (except palatoglossus).
  • Pharyngeal arch - supplied by CN5(mandibular), CN7, CN9, CN10 (superior laryngeal and recurrent laryngeal branch).

questions.text: Which of the following represents a holocrine gland?
questions.solution:
The histopathological image marked ‘B’ represents the sebaceous gland, which is a type of holocrine gland.

Holocrine secretions are produced in the cytoplasm of the cell and released by the rupture of the plasma membrane, which destroys the cell and results in the secretion of the product into the lumen.

Examples of holocrine glands are

  • Sebaceous glands of the skin and
  • Meibomian glands of the eyelid

Image A: Sweat glands - Eccrine/merocrine glands; glands remain intact

Image C: Mammary gland - Apocrine gland; apical part sheds to secrete

Image D: Ceruminous gland - Apocrine glands

questions.text: Microvilli are absent in ______.
questions.solution:
Microvilli are absent in collecting ducts. They are lined by simple columnar epithelium without microvilli.

The simple cuboidal or columnar epithelium may undergo certain specializations such as:

  • Microvilli - long finger-like projections arising from the surface of the epithelium, which increases the surface area of absorption. If the microvilli are long and are arranged regularly, parallel to one another, it gives a striated appearance on light microscopy. However, if the microvilli are arranged irregularly, it gives a brush border appearance. Microvilli are located at:
    • Small intestine - columnar cells with striated microvilli.
    • Gall bladder - columnar cells with brush border microvilli.
    • Proximal convoluted tubule - cuboidal cells with brush border microvilli
  • Stereocilia - long and branching microvilli. Unlike the cilia, the stereocilia are non-motile and hence, the preferred name is stereovilli. They are located at:
    • Epididymis (increase the surface area of absorption)
    • Cochlear and vestibular receptor cells (function as sensory transducers)
  • Cilia - hair-like projections on the epithelial cells that are concerned with the movement. The ciliated columnar epithelium is seen in the lining of the following structures:
    • Respiratory tract except in lower pharynx and vocal folds.
    • Tympanic cavity and auditory tube.
    • Uterine tube and efferent ductules of the testis.
  • Secretory - columnar cells may be specialized for secretions where they are referred to as glandular cells. Such cells form the mucin secreting and chief cells of the gastric epithelium.

questions.text: Which of the following structures passes through the marked foramen?
questions.solution:
The foramen marked is the foramen spinosum. The structures passing through it are: 

  • Middle meningeal artery 
  • Nervus spinosus
  • Middle meningeal vein

Related Pearl: Structures passing through skull foramina

Opening Transmits

  • Ophthalmic arteries

  • Frontal nerve (V1)
  • Nasociliary nerve (V1)

  • Superior ophthalmic vein
  • Inferior ophthalmic vein

  • Maxillary division of CN V (V2)
Foramen ovale
  • Mandibular division of CN V (V3)
  • Accessory meningeal artery
  • Lesser petrosal nerve
  • Emissary veins
Foramen spinosum
  • Middle meningeal artery
  • Nervus spinosus
  • Middle meningeal vein
Foramen lacerum
  • Deep petrosal nerve
  • Meningeal branch of ascending pharyngeal artery 
  • Emissary vein
Carotid canal
  • Internal carotid artery
  • Venous and sympathetic plexus around artery
Jugular foramen
  • Inferior petrosal sinus
  • Meningeal branch of ascending pharyngeal artery 
  • CNs IX,X & XI

Hypoglossal canal

Foramen magnum

    • Lower end of the medulla oblongata with meninges

questions.text: All of the following statements are true except:

choices.text: Vagus nerve emerges via the intermediate compartment of jugular foramen
Galen's anastomosis refers to anastomosis between the internal laryngeal nerve and recurrent laryngeal nerve
Internal laryngeal nerve is accompanied by superior thyroid vessels
Right reccurent laryngeal nerve winds around the 1st part of subclavian artery

questions.solution:
The internal laryngeal nerve is accompanied by the superior laryngeal vessels, not the superior thyroid vessels. Along with superior laryngeal vessels, it pierces the thyrohyoid membrane.

The vagus nerve arises as several rootlets from the medulla which unite to form a single nerve and emerges via the intermediate compartment of the jugular foramen.

Galen's anastomosis is the connecting branch between the inferior laryngeal nerve (a branch of the recurrent laryngeal nerve) and the internal laryngeal nerve (a branch of the superior laryngeal nerve).

Right recurrent laryngeal nerve winds around the lower and posterior part of 1st part of the right subclavian artery and left recurrent laryngeal nerve winds around the arch of the aorta.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the areas marked in the given image?

choices.text: A is a type of association fiber
C is content of interpeduncular fossa
D is devoid of blood brain barrier

questions.solution:
A is anterior commissure, which is a type of commissural fiber, not association fiber.

B is lamina terminalis

C is the mamillary body and is a content of interpeduncular fossa.

D is the pineal gland, which does not have blood-brain barrier.

Related Pearl: White matter tracts of the brain

Commissural fibers: connect corresponding regions of two hemispheres.

They include

  • Corpus callosum
  • Anterior and posterior commissure
  • Habenular commissure
  • Hippocampal commissure of fornix

Association fibers: connect various cortical regions within the same hemisphere.

They are classified as 

  • Short association fibers: lie immediately under the cortex and connect adjacent gyri. Eg- arcuate fasciculus
  • Long association fibers:
    • Uncinate fasciculus
    • Cingulum
    • Superior longitudinal fasciculus
    • Inferior longitudinal fasciculus
    • Fronto-occipital fasciculus
    • Fornix (except hippocampal commissure of fornix)

Projection fibers: fibers passing to and from the brainstem to the cerebral cortex. 

  • Internal capsule
  • Corona radiata

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct about the mediastinum?

choices.text: Heart enclosed in the pericardium occupies the middle mediastinum
Thymus remnants may be present in the middle mediastinum
Posterior boundary of posterior mediastinum corresponds to T1-T4 vertebrae
Lower border of anterior mediastinum extends more inferiorly than posterior mediastinum

questions.solution:
The heart enclosed in the pericardium occupies the middle mediastinum. 

The middle mediastinum is the broadest part of the inferior mediastinum and contains the pericardium, heart, tracheal bifurcation, and corresponding vessels and nerves.

Option B: The thymus or its remnants are present in the superior and anterior mediastinum. 

Option C: The posterior mediastinum is bounded: 

  • Anteriorly by
    • Tracheal bifurcation
    • Pericardium
    • Pulmonary vessels
  • Posteriorly by
    • Bodies of T5-T12 vertebrae 
  • Anteroinferiorly by
    • Arched posterior 1/3rd of the central portion of the diaphragm

Option D: The lower border of the posterior mediastinum extends more inferiorly as compared to the anterior mediastinum. 

Related Pearl: Divisions and contents of the mediastinum

Major contents of thoracic cavity
Superior mediastinum
  • Trachea
  • Esophagus
  • Thoracic duct
  • Thymus
  • Vessels-
    • Aortic arch
    • Left common carotid artery
    • Left subclavian artery
    • Brachiocephalic trunk
    • Right and left brachiocephalic veins
    • Superior vena cava (upper half)
    • Azygos vein near its opening into superior vena cava
  • Left recurrent laryngeal nerve
Inferior mediastinum Anterior
  • Thymus (inferior extension)
  • Mediastinal branches of internal thoracic vessels
  • Sternopericardial ligaments
Middle
  • Heart
  • Phrenic nerve
  • Tracheal bifurcation and bronchi
  • Roots of great vessels
    • Ascending aorta
    • Superior vena cava (lower half)
    • Inferior vena cava
    • Pulmonary trunk and branches
    • Pericardiophrenic arteries and veins
Posterior
  • Thoracic aorta
  • Thoracic duct
  • Esophagus
  • Vagus nerve
  • Azygos vein
  • Hemiazygos vein

questions.text: What are the site and the timing of the origin of the primordial germ cells?

choices.text: Yolk sac, 4th week of embryonic development

questions.solution:
Primordial germ cells originate in the epiblast, during the 2nd week of development.

Primordial germ cells (PGCs) are also known as primitive sex cells. During the 2nd week of development, they originate in the epiblast at the caudal end of the primitive streak. 

They are the precursors of gametes in both genders. They pass through the primitive streak during gastrulation and reach the wall of the yolk sac. They migrate from the yolk sac in the 4th week and reach the developing gonads by the end of the 5th week.

questions.text: A 48-year-old construction worker presented with complaints of unilateral loss of sweating on the face. He had a history of trauma to his back 1 month ago. Examination revealed the following findings. What is the likely site of the lesion?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Horner's or Bernard-Horner's syndrome. It can be caused by the lesion of the white ramus of T1. 

Horner's syndrome is characterized by a constricted pupil (miosis), drooping of the upper eyelid (ptosis), and an absence of sweating of the face (anhidrosis). It occurs due to the disruption of the sympathetic nerve supply.

In the autonomic nervous system, the sympathetic plexus is thoracolumbar and the parasympathetic plexus is craniosacral.

The sympathetic plexus is formed along the side of the spinal cord by white ramus inflow (preganglionic nerve fibers) and gray ramus outflow (postganglionic) and it extends from T1-L2. 

In Horner's syndrome, since the sympathetic inflow is disrupted, the white ramus of the spinal cord is affected as shown below.

The difference between the sympathetic and parasympathetic ganglions are tabulated below.

  Sympathetic ganglions Parasympathetic ganglions
Location Closer to the spinal cord Closer to the organ
Pre-ganglionic fibers Short  Long
Post-ganglionic fibers Long Short

Related Pearl: Horner's syndrome

Horner's Syndrome:

Horner's syndrome occurring due to occulo-sympathetic paresis is characterized by the classic triad of:

  • Mild ptosis (due to paralysis of Muller's muscle).
  • Miosis (due to paralysis of dilator pupillae).
  • Reduced ipsilateral sweating (anhydrosis).

Other features include:

  • Mild enophthalmos,
  • Loss of cilio-spinal reflex,
  • Heterochromia, i.e., the ipsilateral iris is lighter in colour,
  • Pupil is slow to dilate, and there occurs slight elevation of lower eyelid.

Cocaine test (2% to 4%): Small pupils fail to dilate in Horner's syndrome.

In congenital Horner's syndrome, the additional features seen are heterochromia iridis and unilateral straight hair.

questions.text: The only nerve to emerge from ventral aspect of pons is:
questions.solution:
The only nerve to emerge form ventral aspect of pons is Vth cranial nerve. VI, VII, VIII cranial nerve emerge from ponto medullary junction.

Cranial nerves from Pons:

  • Anterolateral surface
    • Trigeminal nerve
      • Motor root (Medial)
      • Sensory root (Lateral)
  • Goove between the pons and the medulla (Medial to lateral)
    • Abducent
    • Facial, 
    • Vestibulocochlear 
  • Posterior surface of the pons (upper half of the floor of the 4th ventricle)
Cranial Nerve origin:
From cerebrum :
  • Cranial nerves 1, 2 (not true nerves, extensions of telencephalon and diencephalon)  
From brainstem:
  • Midbrain: 3, 4
  • Pons: 5, 6, 7, and 8 (vestibular part)
  • Medulla: 8 (vestibular and cochlear parts), 9, 10, 11, and 12

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman came to the obstetrician for in-vitro fertilization. FSH analogs were injected to induce follicular growth and hCG was injected to induce final oocyte maturation. The oocyte was then retrieved transvaginally. The oocyte thus retrieved​ is arrested at which of the following stages?
questions.solution:
The oocyte retrieved after final maturation is the secondary oocyte that is arrested in metaphase of meiosis II.  

Steps of oogenesis after puberty are shown in the image below:

If there is no fertilization, the secondary oocyte fails to complete the second meiotic division and degenerates about 24 hours after ovulation.

In in-vitro fertilization, initially, FSH analogs are administered to induce follicular growth. At this stage, the oocyte is arrested in the prophase stage of meiosis I. The final maturation of the oocyte is induced by the administration of hCG. This causes the oocyte to resume the meiotic division, complete meiosis I, and enter meiosis II. However, the oocyte is arrested in the metaphase of meiosis II until fertilization.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a circumventricular organ?
questions.solution:
Circumventricular organs are those structures in the brain that are devoid of the blood-brain barrier. Adenohypophysis is not devoid of a blood-brain barrier (BBB).

Neurohypophysis is devoid of the blood-brain barrier.

Related Pearl: Circumventricular Organs (CVO)

The following are the circumventricular organs (CVO) or areas devoid of the blood-brain barrier:

  • Pineal body
  • Neurohypophysis
  • Organum Vasculosum of Lamina Terminalis (OVLT)
  • Median Eminence (hypothalamus)
  • Subcommissural organ
  • Subfornical organ
  • Area Postrema

questions.text: A patient presented with tenderness in the region shown below following a fall onto an outstretched hand. Which of the following forms the roof of this region?
questions.solution:
The marked region is the anatomical snuffbox. The superficial branch of radial nerve forms the roof of the anatomical snuffbox. Tenderness in this region is suggestive of a scaphoid fracture, a common injury after a fall on an outstretched hand.

Anatomical snuffbox boundaries: 

Lateral wall:

  • Abductor pollicis longus (APL),
  • Extensor pollicis brevis (EPB)  

Medial wall:

  • Extensor pollicis longus (EPL).

Roof:

  • Cephalic vein
  • Superficial branch of radial nerve

Floor:

  • Radial styloid, Scaphoid, Trapezium, and 1st Metacarpal. 

Only content: Radial artery

The name "snuffbox" originates from the use of this surface for placing and then sniffing powdered tobacco, or snuff.

questions.text: Which part of the dura mater is supplied by all the three branches of the trigeminal nerve?

choices.text: Dura of the anterior cranial fossa
Dura of the the  middle cranial fossa
Dura of the posterior cranial fossa

questions.solution:
The dura of the anterior cranial fossa is supplied by all three branches of the trigeminal nerve.

The nerves involved are:

  • Ophthalmic division - anterior and posterior ethmoidal nerves
  • Maxillary division - nervus meningeus medius
  • Mandibular division - nervus spinosus

questions.text: Identify the tract marked "A" in the given section of the spinal cord.
questions.solution:
The tract marked "A" in the image is the lateral reticulospinal tract.

They originate from the reticular formation of the brain and terminate on the α and γ motor neurons in the spinal cord. They inhibit or facilitate voluntary movement.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman in labour requested for epidural analgesia. Below which level would you administer the anaesthesia?
questions.solution:
Epidural anaesthesia is given during labour and the placement is usually preferred below L1 to avoid injury to the spinal cord. This is because the adult spinal cord terminates at the lower border of the L1 vertebra.

In children, it usually terminates at the upper border of the L3 vertebra. 

Note: Coverage from dermatomes T10 to S1 is necessary for epidural analgesia during labor. For a cesarean section, a block from T4 to S1 is needed. However, since the spinal cord ends at the lower border of L1 in most adults, epidural analgesia is given below this level.

Related Pearl: Extent of important structures/spaces in the Spinal cord

questions.text: True about branches of cerebral part of internal carotid artery are all except:

choices.text: Largest branch is Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA)
Posterior communicating artery runs posteriorly below the IIIrd nerve
Opthalmic artery artery lies below and lateral to optic nerve in optic canal
Anterior Cerebral Artery (ACA) lies medial and superior to optic nerve

questions.solution:
Posterior communicating artery runs posteriorly above the IIIrd cranial nerve.

Internal carotid artery > cerebral part branches (supra-cavernous part) 
Enters subarachnoid space by piercing arachnoid mater, turns posteriorly, divides into the anterior and middle cerebral arteries.
  • Ophthalmic br.
  • PCom.
  • Choroidal br.
  • ACA
  • MCA
Ophthalmic br.
  • 1st br.
  • Near CN2 ( below and lateral ) 
  • Enter Orbit to supply orbital structures 
PCom 
  • Near CN3 ( posterior and superior) 
  • Joins PCA to form the COW 
Choroidal br.
  • Near Optic tract ( posteriorly ) 
  • Enter Inferior horn of lateral ventricles to form choroid plexus.
ACA
  • Near CN2 (runs forward, medial and superior ) 
  • Enter through Longitudinal Fissure 
  • 2 Anastomosis 
    • Opposite side ACA anteriorly (part of COW) 
    • Anastomose with PCA posteriorly
MCA
  • Largest br. 
  • Enters Lateral cerebral Sulcus 
Abbr.
PCom (posterior communicating Artery), ACA (anterior cerebral artery), MCA (middle cerebral artery), COW (circle of willis), CN (cranial nerve),

questions.text: A woman presented with hemiparesis due to a spinal cord tumour. The doctor diagnosed this as a case of Brown- Séquard syndrome. All are true about this syndrome except:

choices.text: Ipsilateral loss of crude touch sensations
Ipsilateral paralysis below the level of lesion

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Brown- Séquard syndrome. Ipsilateral loss of crude touch sensation is not seen in this syndrome.

Brown- Séquard syndrome is the hemisection of the spinal cord. This causes damage to ascending sensory (dorsal column pathway, spinothalamic tract) and descending motor (corticospinal tract) pathways. 

  • The damage to the dorsal column pathway leads to ipsilateral loss of fine touch, vibration, and proprioception below the level of the lesion.
  • The damage to the spinothalamic tract leads to contra­lateral loss of pain and temperature sensation beginning one or two segments below the lesion.
  • The damage to the cor­ticospinal tract produces ipsilateral paralysis of the body.

Related Pearl: Brown Sequard syndrome (Hemisection of spinal cord)

questions.text: Which of the following structures does the cell pointed in arrow inhibit?
questions.solution:
The cell pointed in arrow inhibit deep nuclei of cerebellum.

Image shows a histopathological section of the cerebellum. Cells marked with the arrow in the image are Purkinje cells.

Axons of Purkinje cells form the only output from cerebellar cortex and they project to the deep cerebellar nuclei(mainly dentate nucleus).

Other cells include basket, golgi and stellate cells are inhibitory interneurons. Granule cells receives excitatory inputs from moss fibres and relay onto purkinje cells to exert stimulatory effect.
